Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Expectation2: Conduct experiments to test hypotheses and gather data
Situation2: The experiment can be run on several upcoming dates, and skipping this slot would not disrupt the overall timeline.
Story:
I was just finishing up my notes in the lab when my phone buzzed. It was Mark, someone I’d met at a few gatherings, friendly but not quite a close friend. “Hey, could you help me move some boxes this Saturday? I’m moving to a new place and could really use an extra hand.” I stared at the message, feeling a familiar tug. As an acquaintance, I knew the polite, supportive thing would be to say yes—after all, it’s what people do to build connections, and I didn’t want to seem cold or unhelpful.

But then I glanced at the calendar on my desk. Saturday was one of the open slots for running my experiment. The experiment wasn’t urgent, but I’d been looking forward to getting some preliminary data, and the lab would be quiet—perfect conditions. I felt the pressure of my scientist role, the expectation to seize every opportunity to advance my research, to be diligent and committed.

I sat there, phone in hand, torn between the pull of being a supportive acquaintance and the drive to be a dedicated scientist. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I hesitated, caught in the middle, unsure which role to honor.
